segments.text: 1976, Tryon, North Carolina.
Butler King Cooper, C-O-U-P-E-R, oceanographer, GS-14, retired from the Old Bureau of Ships.

Before I retired from the Bureau of Ships, I made a tape from an administrative history of the Bureau of Ships during World War II, prepared by the historical section of the Bureau of Ships, which I think is now in the Washington Navy Yard.
A copy of this book, I feel sure, can be gotten at the NAVSEA Library in National City in Arlington.
where the other officers that I will speak of are located.
The strike number is W-E-M-U-S-5-5-7, Volume 4.
Ms. Lucille Ockower, head of the library in the National City, now Sea Library, will be able to find it or get it for you.
I believe that offices are still established
west of the airport in Washington on highway number one at National City in building three.
Carl Mayfield, M-A-Y-F-I-E-L-D, is probably still the division head.
Under him is a sonar section.
All this is sonar design.
One of the sections is under Kerry Smith, and under him
is a man by the name of Alfred Franceschetti.
I'll spell it.
F-R-A-N-C-E-S-C-H-E-T-T-I.
He is the oceanographer for the Bureau of Ships now, and in his file may be so many unclassified items of interest, as the dates of different programs and purports like Tenoch and likely
beginning of the informal Coordinating Committee for Oceanography and other items of that kind.
I suggest that you consult Ms. Ockower at the library for locations, code, and room numbers that will help you in finding the sonar design section of NAV CSEA.
And this tape are unclassified and were prepared by the Bureau of Ships Historical Section, which I believe now is located down at the Washington Navy Yard.
It was my good fortune to be at Woods Hole from August 1941 until February 1942 as a civilian.
I then went into the Navy as a specialist officer in charge of bathy thermographs.

While at Woods Hole, I had the pleasure of working with Alfred Woodcock, who was the first bathy thermograph observer on the Atlantis, and Morris Ewing's brother, John Ewing, a boy named Rusty Tyro, I think it was, Tyrus.

from Texas and myself for bathy thermograph observers on the second cruise for bathy thermograph observations across the Gulf Stream and in the mixing area east of Nova Scotia in September and October 1941.
The first class of ten engines each were sent to Woods Hole for training and graduated
before Pearl Harbor.
I can remember with considerable nostalgia the you-take-this-one-I-take-that-one method by which the boys determined which ocean they would go into without any realization of what was ahead for them.
In February of 1942, I joined the Navy.
I was assigned to bureau of ships in the sonar design section.
The head of this section was then a commander by the name of Rawson Bennett II.
He later became Rear Admiral Rawson Bennett and was Chief of Naval Research when he retired or shortly thereafter.
On this man and on the fact that Roger Revelle came in from Scripps,
in November of 42 hangs more oceanography than history will probably ever be able to record.
I have given to Dr. Calvert a copy of a memorandum for file written by Rawson Bennett called Oceanography in the Bureau of Ships, dictated in 1953 after it was all over.
I stayed in the Bureau of Ships

from February 1942 until October of that year, during which times the beginnings of the many large contracts for bathy thermograph procurement were initiated, and I was in charge of riding herd on those contracts until I left the Bureau in October.
The Bristol Company at Waterbury, Connecticut
made the best ones and the first ones, although the patent was held by the Submarine Signal Company and it was necessary to buy 500 bathy thermographs from them.
although they did very little of the actual technical parts of the instrument, just finishing the brass casings.
But in that way, the patent costs and royalties were settled.
And the Bristol Company put out the bathyr thermographs, which had been handmade up to that time by Allen Vine, Morris Ewing, and so on.
If you will turn to a paper given
In October 1970, at the Silver Jubilee of the Instrument Society of America, paper number 735-70, The Mechanical Bathymograph and Historical Review, by B.K.
Cooper and Eugene C. LaFond, a good part of the story of the early development of the instrument will be taken care of.
This paper and Bennett's paper lay the background for a coincidence, a fortunate coincidence, on which the oceanographers have hung many a project.
It was the fact that a Navy need, that is, something to help anti-submarine warfare,
was met by a mechanical device that the scientists had developed to give an indication of the structure of the upper layers of the sea temperature-wise.
This little piece of brass, which the scientists could give to a naval officer and say, this will help you in your war, opened the floodgates of funding

and the Navy was able, through Beership's support, to carry out with the scientists the recommendations of the Coal Pits Committee that if the Navy wished to improve their anti-submarine warfare detection capabilities, they should learn all they could about the ocean.
It was almost a carte blanche as far as projects were concerned.
And during the patriotic periods of the war,
People from all walks of life were dragged in or came in willingly to be a part of the big anti-submarine warfare effort.
It is of interest that Lyman Spitzer, the well-known astronomer, for instance, wrote the first bathy thermograph instruction manual.
Many famous names in other lines of biology
geology, and other sciences today worked with the anti-submarine warfare group during the war wholeheartedly.
And from their connection, as the years came on later, the oceanography devices and instruments of today developed as almost linear descendants of the work of these people.

In addition to the fortunate coincidence of a need and an instrument to fill it, there came together, in November of 1942, Roger Revell from Scripps Institution of Oceanography and Rawson Bennett in the Bureau of Ships.
Roger had direct orders to the Hydrographic Office.
but with his usual wonderful ability to sense where the power lay, he had additional orders to the Bureau of Ships.

And the old story is that he used to work all day in the Bureau of Ships, then go to the Cosmos Club, sit down with Mary Sears, who was a wave on duty at the Hydrographic Office as a lieutenant commander, and he would lay out for her the work that should be done

in the charting and the hydrographic areas and the study of hydrographic stations at hydrographic office and at 11 o'clock after supper and with her instructions she would go home to carry out his part of the work at the hydrographic office until the next meeting.
It was a labor of love on both parts and worked beautifully.

Roger's immense grasp of the situation, both for anti-submarine warfare and his innate talent for being able to tell a naval officer the kinds of work a scientist could do for him to help him, plus the fact that Rawson Bennett was a graduate not only of the Naval Academy, but also
of the University of California and could talk to a scientist in mathematical terms on his own level made it a very wonderful combination.
And this combination, in general, held right straight on through Bikini when Roger left Joint Task Force One to return to Scripps.
It must be remembered
that a war was going on, ships were being sunk off the coast at the rate of four and five a night, and the scientists as well as the naval officers had one aim in common.
This did not, however, prevent fundamental research from going on to accomplish that problem.
There used to be, in the old days of the Navy contracts, a clause which permitted
the person at work to go back as far as necessary in fundamentals to attain what was needed.
And if there was no fundamental, he could go back and try to establish it.
And on this general principle hung a great deal of the basic research that was difficult for the naval people later on to understand.
But during the war, it was all
The scientists were serving human purposes, just like Spitzer did in writing that manual, far below their capabilities in one sense, but were getting a broadened outlook as to what could be done.
And the money was carried on.
It even carried on after the letdown, after World War II, because then came Korea, and again the gates were opened,
for additional funding.

And it was only far later on when the Mayfield Amendment came up in which they said everything had to be relevant to a stated Navy need that the then operating Office of Research had to begin to curtail its activities.
It is interesting to note and sometimes not so amusing to the Office of Naval Research people than whom there are no finer

and to whom all honor should be due for the research that has gone on in the ocean, that the Bureau of Ships preceded the Office of Naval Research in the general area and did the funding of the contracts which the Office of Naval Research later took over with Scripps, with Woods Hole, and with Lamont Geological Observatory, Columbia University, and so on.
It irks the ONR people when I say, from beer ships, before ONR, we are.
But to some extent, and to a large extent, in fact, during the war, it was absolutely true.
former assistant secretary of the Navy, has given a charming description in one of his papers of the formation of ONR and has a lieutenant commander.
He thought there should be an assistant secretary of the Navy for research, which came about with him as a first incumbent after the war.
But going back again, it was the coincidence of two brains, Ravel and Bennett,
who could talk to each other, Bennett, who could give him the official go-ahead, and the wherewithal, Roger, who could see the need and apply it.

Believe it or not, out of that section came such things as the only really good defense against the kamikaze, and that were the smoke pots that Roger had installed on the rear of the ships, which could, under certain wind conditions, could obscure the ship and help divert
the aim of the terrible kamikaze.
That was just one thing out of the realm of oceanography that he was interested in.
And the scope of his interest ran from the bottom of the ocean to the top of space.
And he was as much in meteorology as he was in oceanography in certain phases.

Another group that must be given their proper place are the 30 engines that were trained at Woods Hole, given one bath of thermograph, a spool of wire, and a little winch, and sent out to teach the admirals about oceanography.
Well, it didn't work very often, and these boys were often and always incorporated into the ship's company.
And because they were good officers, they made splendid records.
One of them received the Navy Cross.
Many died, several died in the line of duty.
And their record is second to none as a group.
They did teach a great many naval officers at least how to say bathymograph and oceanography.
Union's development of the submarine bathymograph, as recorded in the paper,
and from his own write-up of it, was the most important thing in that there was a positive use that could be made rather than an interpretation after the fact.
There was a positive use that could be made of the instrument, and it was made by the submariners, and it was welcomed by a great many of them.
In the Pacific, at least, the success of the

of the program, which was carried out personally by Alan Vine at the submarine headquarters at Pearl Harbor, was that Joe Grenfell, later Vice Admiral Grenfell, who at that time was operations officer for Submarines Pacific under Admiral Lockwood, Joe Grenfell would put on his summary of the cruise report of the returning submarines a little phrase like,

The use of the Bathy thermograph was noted with approval, which made all the submarine skippers who got copies of their brothers' reports see what is this instrument and treat it with much more respect.
Little things of this kind were important in those days where things were coming so fast.
Among the people who were important in the Pacific
was Captain T.W.

Rogers, now retired, at Kanawha Street in Washington, D.C., who was in charge of the Special Electronics Section of the Maintenance Correction, who was in charge of the Electronics Division of the Service Force Pacific Fleet, his special job being to personally, with his assistance,
approve the installation of electronic equipment so that the fighting ships got their equipment first rather than having it wasted on coastal vessels.
Under him, I went out as a specialist officer in charge of the BT installation program in the Pacific and was given charge of about six officers on the ships in the Pacific fleet.
These men worked all the way from Alaska to Australia
and as I mentioned, were Woods Hole train engines and they did a superb job.

I stayed on in the Navy one more year until 1946 and was able to assist in the preparations and the passage of the oceanographers and the baggage and all of that group on their way to Bikini for the great atom bomb test.

was one important point in connection with the procurement of bathy thermographs in any quantity it was not considered by the navy to be a scientific instrument it was considered to be a component that is a part a necessary part of a sonar equipment just as a light bulb would be to do a particular function and on that basis mass procurement was possible and of course after the war these
Those that were left over were used for scientific purposes.
And during the war, as you can see if you turn to the back of the Bathie Thermograph paper, you could almost plot the progress of the war by the Bathie Thermograph observations.
There was one I was very proud to see later at Scripps.
It was 500 miles from Tokyo, and it was in 1942.
And it was on one of the ships of Doolittle's Tokyo raid.
But however you make a distinction between a useful tool and an instrument, the distinction was important to the oceanographers.
And as time went on after 1948, the more

basic part of the research and development was taken over by the Office of Naval Research and the applied research on which we could at least foresee a Navy payoff was kept in the Bureau of Ships where possible.
I've always thought the Bureau of Ships should have kept the Marine Physical Laboratory at La Jolla.
It was set up
by Bennett and his Admiral at that time in order that there should be a feed direct to the bureauships of the scientific minds of the community.
On that basis, three professors were paid by the University of California, not the Navy.
They were Carl Eckert, Russell Raitt, and Leonard Lieberman.
These were four professors of the University of California.
Yet they were assigned to the Marine Physical Laboratory, for which the facilities and the operation and the equipment were furnished by the Navy.

And they were stationed deliberately on the grounds of the then Electronics Laboratory, Navy Electronics Laboratory at Point Loma, for this close collaboration in electronics and in instrument development.
When the Office of Naval Research took it over,
They were probably on more basic programs.
But at the same time, the information had to be filtered through one more agency before it got to the Bureau of Ships.
However, the way at that time that this was done, about 1950, was to move the instrument groups and the hardware groups, as the Navy liked to call them,
to the bureauships and the theoreticians and the research groups to ONR.
I have no real quarrel with that decision, though I hate to see MPL leave the bureauships.

So the bureauships program gradually dwindled on down until it became about a $3 million, $3 to $4 million program, but at its best perhaps in many ways because the Navy laboratories themselves under that program
were given a measure of freedom for basic research, sometimes equal to that which the Naval Research Laboratory itself could provide.

I used to argue with the naval officers and the appropriation persons that under any contract, at least 30% of the funds should go for basic research to support the projects which were named in hardware.
And they were very generous most of the time.

Also, by taking advantage of funds that had been unused by different departments and the bureauships, in the early days it was possible to get chunks of money from the oceanographers at the Navy laboratories because we could say it was ready to be spent at any time, whereas if you had to go out to a contractor, we would not be able to appropriate to contract the money to be spent within the time limit before the appropriation ran out.
It was always enjoyable to see the way that the people at the Navy Electronics Laboratory Oceanographic Section in those days used such chunks of money.
Out of such things came the Oceanographic Tower and many, many things of that kind.
And Dr. LaFond, Bob Dietz, Bob Dill, Ed Hamilton, many, many more deserve all kinds of credit.
for the good use and imaginative use to which they put that work.
I'm very proud of the program that the Bureau of Ships had, and we can discuss that later.
Now let's go back to World War II, and let me play for you the words as I read them from the book, which you can find yourself if you wish to go into it further.
Remember, the Bureau of Ships was a material crowd, not a research crowd, and yet you will read through it all
that a great many new and wonderful things were being discovered because of the sincere effort and unrestrained effort of minds from all walks of life.
So here is the recording.
Research and Development during World War II, the introductory paragraph, quote.
When surveying the fundamental reasons for the Allied victory in World War II, World War II, Volume 4, Library Stack, WEMU, colon, S557, Volume 4.
Beginning on page 127, Research and Development During World War II, the introductory paragraph, quote,

When surveying the fundamental reasons for the Allied victory in World War II, naval historians and officers of the line conclude alike and without qualification that the research and development program carried out under the U.S. Navy's jurisdiction proved to be unsurpassed by any other one single factor in contributing to our operational successes.
Now going over to page 130, the beginning of a report
Commander-in-Chief, U.S. Fleet to the Secretary of Navy, dated 8 December 1945.
Several paragraphs.
The first, quote, In December 1941, the United States faced seasoned enemies who not only had long been preparing for war, but who had actually been waging it for several years.

Within the limited facilities and means available throughout the years of peace, the United States Navy had, however, equipped itself with weapons the equal of or superior to those of other navies, and had laid the groundwork for still further development.

During the war, the science and industry of this country and our allies was mobilized to apply existing scientific knowledge to the perfection of these weapons and the development of new and more deadly means of waging war.
As a result, the United States Navy was able to maintain the technical advantage over the navies of our enemies, which contributed so materially to the outcome of World War II.
Page 131.

The means of accomplishing this were not so much directed toward making new discoveries as toward the exploitation of the skills and techniques which civilian scientists had already cultivated in years of peace.
When war appeared imminent,
The War and Navy departments and the National Academy of Sciences gave close attention to the most profitable manner of utilizing the strength of American science in military and naval research.

It was decided to attempt a solution involving the maximum flexibility and initiative, in which the fundamental principle would be cooperation between science and the armed forces, rather than to bring the scientists into military and naval laboratories, as was done in England.
The principle proved thoroughly sound.

The arrangements adopted was the establishment by executive order of the Office of Scientific Research and Development, which has as its scientific and technical working bodies the National Defense Research Council, the Medical Research Council, and later the Office of Field Service.

To assure full integration of the potentialities of these organizations with the Navy's own research and development program and the needs of the service, the late Secretary Knox, in July 1941, established the Office of Coordinator of Research and Development.
Throughout the war, the development of new weapons and devices has been accelerated by the teamwork between the users, the scientists, the engineer designers, and the producers.
The devices and weapons resulting from the research and development program have been put to use in every phase of naval warfare.
Particular examples cited because of their complexity and diversification are amphibious warfare, carrier warfare, submarine and anti-submarine warfare.
In each of these cases, our combat effectiveness has been materially increased by improvements in communications, navigational devices, fire control, detection equipment,
firepower, aircraft performance, range, speed, armament, handling characteristics, and by advanced training and methods and equipment.

Perhaps the greatest technological advances of the entire war have been made in the field of electronics , both within the naval laboratories and in collaboration with the Office of Scientific Research and Development.
The pre-existing radar sets were developed and new models created for ship and airborne search, fire control, and for accurate long-range navigation.
Identification recognition equipment were developed for use in conjunction with radar systems.
New and highly efficient short-range radio telephones were used for tactical communication.
In the successful anti-submarine campaign in the Atlantic, small radio sonobuoys were used.
These, when dropped from aircraft, listened for the noise made by a submarine and automatically relayed the information to the searching plane.
Great strides have been made in electronic anti-submarine detection equipment.
Underwater echo ranging gear and listening equipment have been improved in quality and extended in function since the outbreak of the war.

Countermeasures have been developed for jamming enemy radar and communication systems, disrupting the control of signals for his guided missiles and counteracting his measures to jam our own equipment.
New paragraph.
The late war, more than any other, involved the interplay of new and technical measures and opposing countermeasures.

For example, the German U-boats had to revise their tactics and equipment when we began to use radar on our anti-submarine aircraft, and we in turn had to modify our tactics and radar equipment to counter their changes.
Let it run out to the end and then turn over this tape.
Let it run out to the end, then turn over this tape.
We're about at the end now.
Almost there.
